course_outcomes: Solve the system of homogeneous and non-homogeneous linear equations
Examine the nature of a quadratic form by transforming into a canonical form
Determine maxima and minima of multivariable functions
Evaluate areas and volumes using double, triple integrals

syllabus.title: Matrices
syllabus.topics: Rank of a matrix by Echelon form, Normal form, Cauchy–Binet formulae (without proof), Inverse of Non- singular matrices by Gauss-Jordan method, System of linear equations: Solving system of Homogeneous and Non-Homogeneous equations by Gauss elimination method, Jacobi and Gauss-Seidel Iteration Methods.

syllabus.title: Eigenvalues, Eigenvectors and Orthogonal Transformation
syllabus.topics: Eigenvalues, Eigenvectors and their properties, Diagonalization of a matrix, Cayley Hamilton Theorem (without proof), Finding inverse and power of a matrix by Cayley Hamilton Theorem, Quadratic forms and Nature of the Quadratic forms, Reduction of Quadratic form to Canonical forms by Orthogonal Transformation.

syllabus.title: Differential Calculus
syllabus.topics: Mean Value Theorems: Rolle’s theorem, Lagrange’s mean value theorem with their geometrical interpretation, Cauchy’s mean value theorem, Taylor’s and Maclaurin’s theorems with remainders (without proof), Problems and applications on the above theorems. Functions of Several Variables: Continuity and Differentiability, Partial derivatives, Total derivatives, Chain rule, Directional derivative, Taylor’s and Maclaurin’s series expansion of functions of two variables, Jacobians, Functional dependence, Maxima and Minima of functions of two variables, Method of Lagrange multipliers.

syllabus.title: Multiple Integrals (Multivariable Calculus)
syllabus.topics: Double integrals,Triple integrals, Change of order of integration, Change of variables to polar, cylindrical and spherical coordinates, Finding areas (by double integrals) and volumes (by double integrals and triple integrals).

course_outcomes: Elaborate different types of lasers, optical fibers and their applications
Familiarize with the basics of crystals and their structures
Summarize various types of polarization of dielectrics and classify the magnetic materials
Explain the basic concepts of Quantum Mechanics and types of semiconductors using Hall Effect.

syllabus.title: Lasers and Fiber Optics
syllabus.topics: Lasers: Introduction, Characteristics of laser, Basic Principles of lasers (absorption, spontaneous emission and stimulated emission), Requirements of lasers (pumping, population inversion and cavity resonance), Einstein’s coefficients, different types of lasers: solid-state lasers (Ruby), gas lasers, (He-Ne), Semiconductor laser, applications of lasers in science, engineering and medicine. Fibre Optics: Introduction, Fundamentals of optic fibre, Propagation of light through optical fiber, Types of optical fibers, Numerical aperture, Fractional Refractive Index change, Fiber optics in communication and its advantages.

syllabus.title: Crystallography and X-ray diffraction
syllabus.topics: Crystallography: Space lattice, Basis, Unit Cell and lattice parameters– Bravais Lattices– crystal systems (3D)– coordination number- packing fraction of SC, BCC FCC- Miller indices– separation between successive (hkl) planes. X-ray diffraction: Bragg’s law- X-ray Diffractometer– crystal structure determination by Laue’s and powder methods.

syllabus.title: Dielectric and Magnetic Materials
syllabus.topics: Dielectric Materials: Introduction- Dielectric polarization- Dielectric polarizability, Susceptibility, Dielectric constant and Displacement Vector– Relation between the electric vectors- Types of polarizations- Electronic (Quantitative), Ionic (Quantitative) and Orientation polarizations (Qualitative)- Lorentz internal field- Clausius Mossotti equation- Frequency dependence of polarization– complex dielectric constant (Qualitative)– dielectric loss (Qualitative). Magnetic Materials: Introduction- Magnetic dipole moment- Magnetization Magnetic susceptibility and permeability– Atomic origin of magnetism- Classification of magnetic materials: Dia, Para and Ferro magnetic materials- Domain concept for Ferromagnetism Domain walls (Qualitative)- Hysteresis- soft and hard magnetic materials.

syllabus.title: Quantum Mechanics and Semiconductors
syllabus.topics: Quantum Mechanics: Dual nature of light, Matter waves,Properties and Debroglie’s hypothesis, G.P.Thomson experiment,Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle and its applications (Non existence of electron in nucleus) and properties of wave function– Schrodinger’s time independent and dependent wave equations– Particle in a one-dimensional infinite potential well. Semiconductors: Formation of energy bands– classification of crystalline solids- Intrinsic semiconductors- Fermi level-Extrinsic semiconductors-Fermi level- Drift and diffusion currents– Einstein’s equation– Hall effect and its applications, Photodiode,Light Emitting Diode,Solar cell and its applications.

textbooks: A Text book of Engineering Physics, M. N. Avadhanulu, P.G.Kshirsagar TVS Arun Murthy, S. Chand Publications, 11th Edition 2019.
Engineering Physics- D.K.Bhattacharya and Poonam Tandon, Oxford press (2015)
reference_books: Engineering Physics- B.K. Pandey and S. Chaturvedi, Cengage Learning 2021
Engineering Physics- Shatendra Sharma, Jyotsna Sharma, Pearson Education, 2018.

course_outcomes: Understand various Civil Engineering sub-divisions thereby appreciate their role in ensuring a better society and understand the basic building components along with attaining knowledge of Civil Engineering Materials and prefabricated technology

Know the basic concepts, uses and classification of surveying and realize the importance of Transportation in the nation’s economy and the engineering measures related to Transportation and understand the importance of Water Storage and Conveyance Structures so that the social responsibilities of water conservation will be appreciated
Understand the scope of Mechanical Engineering in different sectors and industries and know about different manufacturing processes
Explain the basics of thermal engineering, Power plants , power transmission and robotics

syllabus.title: Basics of Civil Engineering
syllabus.topics: Role of Civil Engineers in Society- Various Disciplines of Civil Engineering- Structural Engineering- Geo-technical Engineering- Transportation Engineering- Hydraulics and Water Resources Engineering- Environmental Engineering-Scope of each discipline- Building Construction and Planning- Construction Materials-Cement- Aggregate- Bricks- Cement concrete- Steel-Introduction to Prefabricated Construction Techniques.

syllabus.title: Surveying and Transportation Engineering & Water Resources and Environmental Engineering
syllabus.topics: Objectives of Surveying- Principles of Surveying-Classification based on function and instruments, Importance of Transportation in Nation’s Economic Development- Basics components of Road Classification of Highways. Introduction, Sources of water- Quality of water- Specifications- Simple introduction to Dams and Reservoirs.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering
syllabus.topics: Role of Mechanical Engineering in Industries and Society- Technologies in different sectors such as Energy, Manufacturing, Automotive, Aerospace, and Marine sectors. Engineering Materials- Metals Ferrous and Non-ferrous, Ceramics, Composites, Smart materials. Manufacturing Processes: Principles of Casting, joining processes, Machining, Introduction to CNC machines, 3D printing, and Smart manufacturing.

syllabus.title: Thermal Engineering and Mechanical Power Transmission
syllabus.topics: Thermal Engineering: IC engines, 2-Stroke and 4-Stroke engines, SI/CI Engines, Otto cycle,Diesel cycle,Components of Electric and Hybrid Vehicles., Refrigeration and air conditioning Working principle of Boilers: classification of Boilers Power plants– Working principle of Steam, Nuclear power plants. Mechanical Power Transmission- Belt and Gear Drives, Introduction to Robotics.

course_outcomes: To introduce students to the fundamentals of computer programming
Toprovide hands-on experience with coding and debugging on control structures and arrays
To foster logical thinking and problem-solving skills on strings and ponters
To familiarize students with programming concepts such as functions, structures and files

syllabus.title: Introduction to Programming and Problem Solving
syllabus.topics: History of Computers, Basic organization of a computer: ALU, input-output units, memory, program counter, Introduction to Programming Languages, Basics of a Computer Program- Algorithms, flowcharts (Using Dia Tool), pseudo code. Introduction to Compilation and Execution, Primitive Data Types, Variables, and Constants, Basic Input and Output, Operations, Type Conversion, and Casting. Problem solving techniques: Algorithmic approach, characteristics of algorithm, Problem solving strategies: Top-down approach, Bottom-up approach, Time and space complexities of algorithms.

syllabus.title: Control Structures and Arrays
syllabus.topics: Simple sequential programs Conditional Statements (if, if-else, switch), Loops (for, while, do- while) Break and Continue, Arrays indexing, memory model, programs with array of integers, two dimensional arrays.

syllabus.title: Strings and pointers
syllabus.topics: Introduction to Strings. Pointers, dereferencing and address operators, pointer and address arithmetic, array manipulation using pointers.

syllabus.title: Functions, User Defined Data types and File Handling
syllabus.topics: Introduction to Functions, Function Declaration and Definition, Function call Return Types and Arguments, modifying parameters inside functions using pointers, arrays as parameters. Scope and Lifetime of Variables, User-defined data types-Structures and Unions, Basics of File Handling

textbooks: ”The C Programming Language”, Brian W. Kernighan and Dennis M. Ritchie, Prentice- Hall, 1988
Schaum’s Outline of Programming with C, Byron S Gottfried, McGraw-Hill Education, 1996.

C Programming,A Problem Solving Approach,Forouzan,Gilberg,Prasad, CENGAGE, 3rd edition.

metadata.prerequisites: Basic understanding of the language skills viz Listening, Speaking, Reading and Writing, including Sentence construction abilities
course_outcomes: Understand the context, topic, and pieces of specific information from social or Transactional dialogues
Apply grammatical structures to formulate sentences and correct word forms
Analyze discourse markers to speak clearly on a specific topic in informal discussions
Evaluate reading texts / listening to write summaries based on global comprehension and create a coherent paragraph, essay and r´esum´e

syllabus.title: Human Values
syllabus.topics: Lesson: HUMAN VALUES: Gift of Magi (Short Story). Listening: Identifying the topic, the context and specific pieces of information by listening to short audio texts and answering a series of questions. Speaking: Asking and answering general questions on familiar topics such as home, family, work, studies and interests; introducing oneself and others. Reading: Skimming to get the main idea of a text; scanning to look for specific pieces of information. Writing: Mechanics of Writing-Capitalization, Spellings, Punctuation-Parts of Sentences. Grammar: Parts of Speech, Basic Sentence Structures-forming questions. Vocabulary: Synonyms, Antonyms, Affixes (Prefixes/Suffixes), Root words.

syllabus.title: Nature
syllabus.topics: Lesson: NATURE: The Brook by Alfred Tennyson (Poem). Listening: Answering a series of questions about main ideas and supporting ideas after listening to audio texts. Speaking: Discussion in pairs/small groups on specific topics followed by short structure talks. Reading: Identifying sequence of ideas; recognizing verbal techniques that help to link the ideas in a paragraph together. Writing: Structure of a paragraph- Paragraph writing (specific topics). Grammar: Cohesive devices- linkers, use of articles and zero article; prepositions. Vocabulary: Homonyms, Homophones, Homographs.

syllabus.title: Biography
syllabus.topics: Lesson: BIOGRAPHY: Elon Musk. Listening: Listening for global comprehension and summarizing what is listened to. Speaking: Discussing specific topics in pairs or small groups and reporting what is discussed. Reading: Reading a text in detail by making basic inferences-recognizing and interpreting specific context clues; strategies to use text clues for comprehension. Writing: Summarizing, Note-making, paraphrasing, Essay Writing, (The Power of Intrapersonal Communication). Grammar: Verbs- tenses; subject-verb agreement; Compound words, Collocations. Vocabulary: Compound words, Collocations.

syllabus.title: Inspiration
syllabus.topics: Lesson: INSPIRATION: The Toys of Peace by Saki. Listening: Making predictions while listening to conversations/ transactional dialogues without video; listening with video. Speaking: Role plays for practice of conversational English in academic contexts (formal and informal)- asking for and giving information/directions. Reading: Studying the use of graphic elements in texts to convey information, reveal trends/patterns/relationships, communicate processes or display complicated data. Writing: Letter Writing: Official Letters, Resumes & Report Writing. Grammar: Reporting verbs, Direct & Indirect speech, Active & Passive Voice. Vocabulary: Words often confused, Jargons & Technical Jargons.

textbooks: Pathfinder: Communicative English for Undergraduate Students, 1st Edition, Orient Black Swan, 2023 (Units 1,2 & 3)
Empowering with Language by Cengage Publications, 2023 (Units 4 & 5).
English: Language, Context and Culture, 1st Edition, Orient Black Swan, 2023 (Units5)

course_outcomes: Test optical components using principles of interference and diffraction of light
Use spectrometer, travelling microscope and function generator in various experiments
Determine the V-I characteristics of photo cells and appreciate the accuracy in measurements

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: Determination of radius of curvature of a given Plano-convex lens by Newton’s rings.
Study the variation of B versus H by magnetizing the magnetic material (B-H curve).
Determination of wavelength of Laser light using diffraction grating
Estimation of stopping potential and work function of a photo material using photoelectric effect.
Magnetic field along the axis of a current carrying circular coil by Stewart Gee’s Method.
Determination of Hall voltage and Hall coefficient of a given semiconductor using Hall Effect.
Determination of Acceleration due to Gravity and radius of Gyration by using a compound pendulum.
Sonometer: Verification of laws of stretched string.
Determination of Dielectric constant of different solid materials.
Determination of Numerical Aperture of a given optical fiber.
Determination of Frequency of electrically maintained tuning fork by Melde’s experiment.
Determination of Rigidity Modulus of the material of the given wire using Torsional pendulum.
Determination of wavelengths of different spectral lines in mercury spectrum using diffraction grating in normal incidence configuration.
Determination of Energy Gap of a semiconductor using p-n junction diode.
Determination of thickness of a thin foil by Wedge Method.
Estimation of Fill Factor of a given Solar Cell.
Study the frequency response and determination of resonating frequency of LCR Circuit.
Determination of Figure of merit of a Galvanometer.

textbooks: MadhusudhanRao,“EngineeringPhysicsLabManual”, Isted.,ScitechPublications,2015.
RamaraoSri,ChoudaryNityanandandPrasadDaruka,”LabManualofEngineeringPhysics”.,Vthed.,ExcellBooks,2010.

course_outcomes: Read, understand, and trace the execution of programs written in C language
Select the right control structure for solving the problem
Develop C programs which utilize memory efficiently using programming constructs like pointers
Develop, Debug and Execute programs to demonstrate the applications of arrays, functions, basic concepts of pointers in C

syllabus.title: Introduction and Basic Operations
syllabus.topics: Week 1: Familiarization with programming environment (Linux, Vi, gcc), simple printf/scanf programs. Week 2: Problem-solving using Algorithms and Flow charts, converting them to C code (e.g., sum, average, temp conversion). Week 3: Variable types, type conversions, and simple computational problems using arithmetic expressions (e.g., square root, compound interest).

syllabus.title: Operators and Control Structures
syllabus.topics: Week 4: Operators, precedence, and associativity with computational problems. Week 5: Branching and logical expressions using if-then-else structures (e.g., max/min, electricity bill, quadratic roots). Week 6: Iterative problems using loops (while, for), including sum of series, factorial, prime check, and palindrome.

syllabus.title: Arrays and Strings
syllabus.topics: Week 7: 1D Array manipulation and linear search (min/max, reverse, 2's complement). Week 8: 2D arrays (matrix problems), string operations, and bubble sort.

syllabus.title: Pointers, Structures, and Dynamic Memory
syllabus.topics: Week 9: Pointers, structures, and dynamic memory allocation (malloc, calloc, realloc, free). Week 10: Bitfields, self-referential structures, and linked lists.

syllabus.title: Functions, Recursion, and File Handling
syllabus.topics: Week 11: Simple functions using call by value. Week 12: Recursive functions (Fibonacci, factorial). Week 13: Functions using call by reference. Week 14: File operations (text and binary files).

textbooks: Ajay Mittal, Programming in C: A practical approach, Pearson.
Byron Gottfried, Schaum's Outline of Programming with C, McGraw Hill.
reference_books: Brian W. Kernighan and Dennis M. Ritchie, The C Programming Language, Prentice- Hall of India
C Programming, A Problem-Solving Approach, Forouzan, Gilberg, Prasad, CENGAGE

metadata.prerequisites: Basic understanding of the language skills viz Listening, Speaking, Reading and Writing, including Sentence construction abilities.
course_outcomes: Understand the different aspects of the English language proficiency with emphasis on LSRW skills
Apply communication skills through various language learning activities
Analyze the English speech sounds, stress, rhythm, intonation and syllable division for better listening and speaking comprehension
Evaluate and exhibit professionalism in participating in debates and group discussions

syllabus.title: List of Topics
topics: Vowels and Consonants
Neutralization/Accent Rules
Communication Skills & JAM
Role Play or Conversational Practice
E-mail Writing
Resume Writing, Cover Letter, SOP
Group Discussions-methods & practice
Debates– Methods & Practice
PPT Presentations/Poster Presentations
Interview Skills

course_outcomes: Understand the basic joints using wood and familiarize with various fundamental aspects of house wiring, fitting and foundry.
Prepare basic models using sheet metal and practice joining of metals using various types of welding.
Familiarize with various advanced manufacturing processes such as injection moulding and 3D printing.
Understand the preparation of PCB and simple IOT applications using Arduino.

syllabus.title: Core Trades
topics: Demonstration: Safety practices and precautions.
Wood Working: Make Half–Lap joint and Bridle joint.
Sheet Metal Working: Develop a Tapered tray and Conical funnel.
Fitting: Perform V-fit, Semi-circular fit, and bicycle/two-wheeler tire maintenance.
Electrical Wiring: Make parallel, series, two-way switch, godown lighting, and tube light connections.
Foundry Trade: Prepare Green Sand moulds for given Patterns.
Welding Shop: Prepare Lap joint and Butt joint using Arc and Gas welding.
Advanced manufacturing processes: Demonstration of injection moulding and 3D printing.
Electronic Circuits: Preparation of a simple electronic circuit (PCB) and testing.
Basic IOT: Use Arduino to measure Temperature & Humidity and Distance.

syllabus.title: Group Activity
syllabus.topics: Students must prepare a Working model / Assembly using the knowledge gained from the above trades.

course_outcomes: Perform Hardware troubleshooting
Understand Hardware components and inter dependencies
Safeguard computer systems from viruses/worms
Document/ Presentation preparation
Perform calculations using spreadsheets

syllabus.title: PC Hardware and OS Installation
syllabus.topics: Task 1: Identify peripherals and CPU components. Task 2: Disassemble and assemble a PC. Task 3: Install MS Windows. Task 4: Install Linux as a dual boot system. Task 5: Install BOSS as a dual boot system.

syllabus.title: Internet and World Wide Web
syllabus.topics: Task 1: Configure TCP/IP settings to connect to the Internet. Task 2: Customize web browsers with proxy settings and plug-ins. Task 3: Use search engines effectively. Task 4: Configure computer for cyber hygiene to avoid viruses and worms.

syllabus.title: Productivity Tools (LaTeX, Word, Excel, PowerPoint)
syllabus.topics: LaTeX and WORD: Create project certificates, abstracts, and newsletters covering formatting, tables, headers/footers, and mail merge. EXCEL: Create schedulers and calculate GPA using formulas, charts, cell referencing, and conditional formatting. POWER POINT: Create presentations covering slide layouts, inserting objects, master layouts, and design templates.

syllabus.title: AI Tools – ChatGPT
syllabus.topics: Task 1: Experiment with different types of prompts (Prompt Engineering). Task 2: Use the model as a creative writing assistant. Task 3: Experiment with language translation tasks.

course_outcomes: Solve first order linear differential equations
Solve higher order linear differential equations with constant coefficients
Solve Partial differential equations
Evaluate the work done against field, circulation and flux using vector calculus

syllabus.title: Differential equations of first order and first degree
syllabus.topics: Linear differential equations– Bernoulli’s equations- Exact equations and equations reducible to exact form, Applications: Newton’s Law of cooling– Law of natural growth and decay- Electrical circuits.

syllabus.title: Linear differential equations of higher order (Constant Coefficients)
syllabus.topics: Definitions,homogenous and non-homogenous, complimentary function, general solution, particular integral, Wronskian, Method of variation of parameters, Simultaneous linear equations, Applications to L-C-R Circuit problems and Simple Harmonic motion.

syllabus.title: Partial Differential Equations
syllabus.topics: Introduction and formation of Partial Differential Equations by elimination of arbitrary constants and arbitrary functions, solutions of first order linear equations using Lagrange’s method, Homogeneous Linear Partial differential equations with constant coefficients.

syllabus.title: Vector Calculus
syllabus.topics: Scalar and vector point functions, vector operator Del, Del applies to scalar point functions- Gradient, Directional derivative, del applied to vector point functions Divergence and Curl, vector identities. Line integral-circulation-work done, surface integral-flux, Green’s theorem in the plane (without proof), Stoke’s theorem (without proof), volume integral, Divergence theorem (without proof) and related problems.

course_outcomes: Apply the principles of quantum mechanics for determining structure and bonding of molecules
Apply the principles electrochemistry for its applications in chemical analysis, electrodes, electrochemical sensors and energy sources
Explain the mechanistic aspects of polymerisation and conduction, types, preparation, properties and applications of polymers
Compare different spectroscopic and chromatographic techniques for their application in qualitative and quantitative analysis
Choose engineering materials including nanomaterials based on their properties for their applications in various industrial fields

syllabus.title: Structure and Bonding Models & Engineering Materials
syllabus.topics: Fundamentals of Quantum mechanics, Schrodinger wave equation, significance of Ψ and Ψ2, particle in one dimensional box, Molecular orbital theory, bonding in homo and heteronuclear diatomic molecules, energy level diagrams of O2,N2, NOand CO,calculation of bond order,- molecular orbitals of butadiene and benzene. Engineering Materials: Semiconductors- Introduction, basic concept, applications, Superconductors- Introduction, basic concept, applications, Supercapacitors- Introduction, basic concept, classification, applications.

syllabus.title: Electrochemistry & Electrochemical Energy Systems
syllabus.topics: Electrochemical cell, Nernst equation, potential and emfcalculations and numerical problems, potentiometry– potentiometric titrations (redox titrations), concept of conductivity, conductivity cell, cell constant and specific conductance, conductometric titrations (acid-base titrations), Electrochemical sensors– potentiometric sensors and amperometric sensors-principle with examples. Electrochemical Energy Systems: Types of electrochemical energy systems- Primary cells– Zinc-air battery, Secondary cells– lithium-ion batteries– working of the batteries including cell reactions, Fuel cells– hydrogen–oxygen fuel cell- working of the cells, Polymer Electrolyte Membrane fuel cells(PEMFC).

syllabus.title: Polymer Chemistry
syllabus.topics: Introduction to polymers, functionality of monomers, addition and condensation polymerization, mechanism of chain growth and step growth polymerization, coordination polymerization with specific examples.Plastics– Thermo and thermosetting plastics, preparation, properties and applications of PVC, Teflon, Bakelite, Nylon 6,6.Elastomers– Buna-S, Buna-N–Preparation, properties and applications. Conducting Polymers– Principle and examples, mechanism of conduction in undoped, doped polyacetylene and applications, Biodegradable polymers– polyglycolic acid (PGA), Polylacticacid(PLA).

syllabus.title: Instrumental Methods of Analysis & Nano materials
syllabus.topics: Electromagnetic spectrum, Interaction of radiation with matter, UV Visible Spectroscopy principle, electronic transitions, Lambert-Beer’s law, Instrumentation, applications,IR spectroscopy-principle, types of vibrations, selection rule, Instrumentation, Chromatography- basic principle and classification. Nano materials: Introduction, classification of nanomaterials. Properties and applications of fullerenes, carbon nanotubes, graphene and nanoparticles.

course_outcomes: Apply different techniques to solve DC circuits
Understand the magnetic circuit concepts
Analyze the steady-state response, series, parallel AC circuits, mesh & nodal analysis, and resonance
Apply network theorems for AC & DC circuits
Demonstrate the working principles of basic Electronic devices, circuits and instrumentation System
Implementation of simple Combinational and Sequential circuits using Logic gates

syllabus.title: DC & AC Circuits
syllabus.topics: DC Circuits: Electrical circuit elements (R, L and C), Ohm’s Law and its limitations, KCL & KVL, series, parallel, series-parallel circuits, Super Position theorem, Simple numerical problems. AC Circuits: A.C. Fundamentals: Equation of AC Voltage and current, waveform, time period, frequency, amplitude, phase, phase difference, average value, RMS value, form factor, peak factor, Voltage and current relationship with phasor diagrams in R, L, and C circuits, Concept of Impedance, Active power, reactive power and apparent power, Concept of power factor (Simple Numerical problems). Equipment Safety Measures: Working principle of Fuse and Miniature circuit breaker (MCB), merits and demerits. Personal safety measures: Electric Shock, Earthing phenomenon, Safety Precautions to avoid shock.

syllabus.title: Machines and Measuring Instruments
syllabus.topics: Machines: Construction, principle and operation of (i) DC Motor, (ii) DC Generator, (iii) Single Phase Transformer, (iv) Three Phase Induction Motor and (v) Alternator, Applications of electrical machines. Measuring Instruments: Construction and working principle of Voltage, Current, temperature sensors, basic block diagram of multimeter. Electricity bill: Power rating of household appliances including air conditioners, PCs, Laptops, Printers, etc. Definition of “unit” used for consumption of electrical energy, calculation of electricity bill for domestic consumers.

syllabus.title: Semiconductor Devices
syllabus.topics: Introduction: Evolution of electronics, Vacuum tubes to nano electronics, Characteristics of PN Junction Diode, Zener Effect — Zener Diode and its Characteristics. Bipolar Junction Transistor, CB, CE, CC Configurations and Characteristics, Elementary Treatment of Small Signal CE Amplifier. Rectifiers and power supplies: Block diagram description of a dc power supply, working of a full wave bridge rectifier, capacitor filter (no analysis), working of simple zener voltage regulator. Amplifiers: Block diagram of Public Address system, Circuit diagram. Electronic Instrumentation: Block diagram of an electronic instrumentation system.

syllabus.title: Digital Electronics
syllabus.topics: Overview of Number Systems, Logic gates including Universal Gates, BCD codes, Excess-3 code, Gray code, Hamming code. Boolean Algebra, Basic Theorems and properties of Boolean Algebra, Truth Tables and Functionality of Logic Gates– NOT, OR, AND, NOR,NAND, XOR and XNOR. Simple combinational circuits–Half and Full Adders. Introduction to Flip flops, Registers and counters (Elementary Treatment only).

textbooks: Basic Electrical Engineering, D. P. Kothari and I. J. Nagrath, Mc Graw Hill, 2019, Fourth Edition.
Principles of Power Systems, V.K. Mehtha, S.Chand Technical Publishers, 2020.
Basic Electrical Engineering, T. K. Nagsarkar and M. S. Sukhija, Oxford University Press, 2017.
Basic Electrical and Electronics Engineering, S. K. Bhatacharya, Person Publications, 2018, Second Edition.
R.L.Boylestad & Louis Nashlesky,Electronic Devices & Circuit Theory, Pearson Education,2021.
P. Jain,ModernDigitalElectronics, 4thEdition,TataMcGrawHill, 2009.
reference_books: R.S.Sedha,ATextbookofElectronicDevicesandCircuits,S.Chand&Co, 2010.
SantiramKal,BasicElectronics-Devices,CircuitsandITFundamentals,PrenticeHall, India,2002.
R.T.Paynter,IntroductoryElectronicDevices&Circuits–ConventionalFlow Version,PearsonEducation,2009

course_outcomes: Demonstrate the role of data structures in organizing and accessing data efficiently
Understand various techniques for searching, sorting and hashing algorithms used to solve complex problems
Demonstrate the operations on linear data structures like stack, queue and linked list
Analyze various operations on nonlinear data structures– binary tree, and binary search tree

syllabus.title: Basic Concepts, Searching and Sorting
syllabus.topics: Basic Concepts: Overview: System life cycle. Algorithm Specification, Data Abstraction, Performance Analysis, the Abstract Data Type. Searching: Introduction to searching, Linear Search and Binary Search. Sorting: Bubble Sort, Insertion Sort, Selection Sort.

syllabus.title: Linked Lists and Stacks
syllabus.topics: Linked Lists: Linked lists, programming details, doubly linked lists, circularly linked lists, Examples: polynomial addition. Stacks: Stack Model, Implementation of Stacks (arays), Linked Stacks Applications: balancing the symbols, postfix expressions, infix to postfix conversionr.

syllabus.title: Queues and Trees
syllabus.topics: Queues: Queue Model, Array implementation of Queues, Applications of Queues: DFS, linked Queues, Types of Queues: Circular Queues, Dequeues. Trees: Introduction, Binary Trees, Binary Tree traversals, Binary Search Tree Definition, Search, Insertion, & Deletion.

syllabus.title: Graphs and Hashing
syllabus.topics: Graphs: Graph Abstract Datatype, Elementary Graph Operations- DFS, BFS. Hashing: General idea, Hash Functions, separate chaining, open addressing, rehashing, extendable hashing.

textbooks: BMark Allen Weiss , “Data Structures and algorithm analysis in C”, Pearson, 2nd Edition, 2016.
Ellis Horowitz, Sartaj Sahni, Susan Anderson-Freed , “Fundamentals of data structures in C”, University Press, 2020
reference_books: Reema Thareja , “ Data Structures Using C ”, Second Edition, 2014, Oxford University Press.
Brad Miller and David Ranum , “Problem Solving with Algorithms and Data Structures” , 2013.
Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, and Clifford Stein, “Introduction to Algorithms” , 3rd Edition, Mitpress.
YedidyahLangsam, Moshe J. Augenstein and Aaron M. Tenenbaum, “Data Structures using C and C++”, 2nd edition, Pearson Education, 1999.
Jean Paul Trembley and Paul G. Sorenson, “An Introduction to Data Structures with Applications”, 2nd edition, McGraw Hill, 2008.

course_outcomes: Understand the principles of engineering drawing, including engineering curves and scales
Draw and interpret orthographic projections of points, lines and planes in front, top and side views
Understand and draw projection of solids in various positions in first quadrant and Explain principles behind development of surfaces
Explain principles behind the Sections of solids, Prepare isometric views and conversion of simple solids

syllabus.title: Introduction to Drawing, Curves and Scales
syllabus.topics: Introduction: Lines, Lettering and Dimensioning, Geometrical Constructions of regular polygons by general methods. Curves: Construction of ellipse, parabola and hyperbola by general method and Involutes. Draw normal and tangent to Curves. Scales: Plain scales and diagonal scales.

syllabus.title: Orthographic Projections
syllabus.topics: Reference plane, importance of reference lines or Plane, Projections of a point situated in first quadrant only. Projections of Straight Lines: Projections of straight lines parallel to both reference planes, perpendicular to one reference plane and parallel to other reference plane, inclined to one reference plane and parallel to the other reference plane. Projections of Straight Line Inclined to both the reference planes. Projections of Planes: Regular planes Perpendicular to both reference planes, parallel to one reference plane and inclined to the other reference plane; plane inclined to both the reference planes.

syllabus.title: Projections of Solids and Development of Surfaces
syllabus.topics: Projections of Solids: Projections of solids(Prisms and Pyramids only) in simple positions: Axis perpendicular to horizontal plane, Axis perpendicular to vertical plane and Projection of Solids with axis inclined to one reference plane and parallel to another plane. Development of Surfaces: Methods of Development: Parallel line development and radial line development. Development of a cube, prism, cylinder, pyramid and cone. Computer graphics: Creating 2D & 3D drawings of objects including PCB and Transformations using Auto CAD (Not for end examination).

syllabus.title: Sections of Solids and Isometric Views
syllabus.topics: Sections of Solids: Section planes perpendicular to VP and inclined to HP only, Sectional views (Front View and Top View only) and Sections of solids in simple position only. Isometric Views: Draw an Isometric views of Simple solids. Conversion of Views: Conversion of isometric views to orthographic views of Simple solids.

textbooks: N. D. Bhatt, Engineering Drawing, Charotar Publishing House, 2016.
reference_books: Engineering Drawing, Basant Agrawal and C M Agrawal,Tata McGraw Hill, 2009.
Engineering Drawing, K.L. Narayana and P. Kannaiah, Tata McGraw Hill, 2013.
Engineering Drawing, M.B.Shah and B.C. Rana, Pearson Education Inc,2009.
Engineering Drawing with an Introduction to Auto CAD, Dhananjay Jolhe , Tata McGraw Hill, 2017.

metadata.prerequisites: Knowledge of chemistry practicals at Intermediate level
course_outcomes: Analyze acids from batteries and metal ions in solutions based on volumetric method
Apply standard procedures for preparation of nanomaterials, polymers and blueprinting
Analyze different solutions by applying various instrumental methods like conductometry, potentiometry, colorimetry, and chromatography

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: Determination of strength of acid in Lead-acid battery
Determination of ferrous iron by dichrometry
Determination of ferrous iron by permanganometry
Conductometric titration of a strong acid vs. strong base
Verification of Lambert-Beer’s law
Potentiometric titration of a redox reaction
Chemistry of blueprinting
Conductometric titration of a weak acid vs. strong base
Determination of cell constant and conductance of solutions
Preparation of nanomaterials– Precipitation method
Preparation of urea-formaldehyde resin
Separation of ions by paper chromatography

reference_books: “Vogel’s quantitative chemical analysis”, 6th Edition, by J. Mendham, R.C. Denney, J.D. Barnes and B. Sivasankar, Pearson Publications.

course_outcomes: Analyze the role of linear data structures in organizing and accessing data efficiently in algorithms
Design, implement, and apply linked lists for dynamic data storage, demonstrating understanding of memory allocation
Develop programs using stacks to handle recursive algorithms, manage program states, and solve related problems

Apply queue-based algorithms for efficient task scheduling and breadth-first traversal in graphs and distinguish between deques and priority queues and apply them appropriately to solve data management challenges

topics.Week 1: Programs on Searching operation (Linear & Binary Search, array reversal).
topics.Week 2: Sorting Techniques Implementation (Bubble sort, Selection sort, Insertion sort).
topics.Week 4: Linked List Applications (polynomial addition, duplicate removal).
topics.Week 5: Double Linked List and Circular Linked list Implementation.
topics.Week 6: Stack Operations (using arrays and linked lists).
topics.Week 7: Queue Operations (using arrays and linked lists).
topics.Week 8: Stack and Queue Applications (infix to postfix, palindrome check).
topics.Week 9: Binary Search Tree Implementation (create, insert, delete, traversal).
topics.Week 10: Programs on hashing (collision resolution, simple cache).
topics.Week 11: Programs on Graph data structures (Depth First Search, Breadth First Search).

textbooks: Data Structures and algorithm analysis in C, Mark Allen Weiss, Pearson, 2nd Edition.
Fundamentals of data structures in C, Ellis Horowitz, Sartaj Sahni, Susan Anderson- Freed, Silicon Press, 2008.
reference_books: Algorithms and Data Structures: The Basic Toolbox by Kurt Mehlhorn and Peter Sanders
C Data Structures and Algorithms by Alfred V. Aho, Jeffrey D. Ullman, and John E. Hopcroft
Problem Solving with Algorithms and Data Structures” by Brad Miller and David Ranum
Introduction to Algorithms by Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, and Clifford Stein
Algorithms in C, Parts 1-5 (Bundle): Fundamentals, Data Structures, Sorting, Searching, and Graph Algorithms by Robert Sedgewick

metadata.course_name: Health and wellness, Yoga and Sports
course_outcomes: Understand the importance of yoga and sports for Physical fitness and sound health
Demonstrate an understanding of health-related fitness components
Compare and contrast various activities that help enhance their health
Assess current personal fitness levels
Develop Positive Personality

syllabus.title: Health and Fitness Concepts
syllabus.topics: Concept of health and fitness, Nutrition and Balanced diet, basic concept of immunity, Relationship between diet and fitness, Globalization and its impact on health, Body Mass Index (BMI). Activities include organizing health awareness programmes and preparing health profiles/charts.

syllabus.title: Yoga
syllabus.topics: Concept of yoga, need for and importance of yoga, origin and history of yoga, classification of yoga, Physiological effects of Asanas- Pranayama and meditation, stress management, Mental health and yoga practice. Activities include Yoga practices like Asana, Kriya, Mudra, Bandha, Dhyana, Surya Namaskar.

syllabus.title: Sports and Fitness
syllabus.topics: Concept of Sports and fitness, importance, fitness components, history of sports, Ancient and Modern Olympics, Asian games and Commonwealth games. Activities include participation in major games and individual sports, practicing warm-ups, aerobics, and cardiorespiratory fitness tests.

reference_books: Gordon Edlin, Eric Golanty. Health and Wellness, 14th Edn. Jones & Bartlett Learning, 2022.
T.K.V.Desikachar. The Heart of Yoga: Developing a Personal Practice.
Archie J.Bahm. Yoga Sutras of Patanjali, Jain Publishing Company, 1993
Wiseman, John Lofty, SAS Survival Handbook: The Ultimate Guide to Surviving Anywhere Third Edition, William Morrow Paperbacks, 2014.
The Sports Rules Book/ Human Kinetics with Thomas Hanlon.– 3rd ed. Human Kinetics, Inc.2014.

course_outcomes: Understand the concepts of Design Thinking
Investigate a problem to determine its root cause
Able to develop design thinking skills and experiment with different solutions
Able to develop prototypes and can test

syllabus.title: Introduction to Design Thinking
syllabus.topics: Design Thinking Overview, Defining Design Thinking, Features and principles of Design thinking, Applications of Design Thinking.

syllabus.title: Modules of Design Thinking (Inspiration & Empathy)
syllabus.topics: Inspiration, methods & tools used in Explore and Empathize phases of Design Thinking, Case study-activity.

syllabus.title: Modules of Design Thinking (Continued)
syllabus.topics: Inspiration, methods & tools used in Explore and Empathize phases of Design Thinking, Case study-activity.

syllabus.title: Prototype and Test Techniques
syllabus.topics: Types of Prototypes, Exercise: Revise Franken Prototype to Refined Prototype, Forms of Testing in Design Thinking, Prepare and Test of the Prototype.

textbooks: Design Thinking: A guide to creative problem solving for everyone, Andrew Pressman, Routledge Taylor and Francis group, 2019, 1st edition.
“Design Thinking for Entrepreneurs and Small Businesses” by Beverly Rudkin Ingle, Apress.
“Design Thinking- The Guide Book”– Facilitated by the Royal Civil Service Commission, Bhutan.
Idris Mootee, “Design Thinking for Strategic Innovation”, John Wiley & Sons (2013).
reference_books: KarmicDesign Thinking- A Buddhism-Inspired Method to Help Create Human Centered Products & Services, Dr Bala Ramadurai.
Design Thinking: A Beginners Perspective EB is written by Balagurusamy and published by Mc Graw-Hill Education India.
Design Thinking: A framework for applying Design Thinking in Problem Solving, Anujuna Agarwal Edition : 1st,2024.

course_outcomes: Understand various forms of organizations and principles of management
Understand the various aspects of business economics.
Perceive the knowledge on Human resources and Marketing functions
Evaluate various alternatives economically.

syllabus.title: Business Organization and Management
syllabus.topics: Forms of Business Organization: Salient Features of Sole Proprietorship, Partnership, Joint Stock Company, Co-operative Society and Public Sector. Management: Introduction to Management, Functions of Management, Principles of Scientific Management, Modern Principles of Management.

syllabus.title: Economics, Demand, and Supply Analysis
syllabus.topics: Introduction to Economics: Basic Economic Concepts, Utility Analysis: Marginal Utility and Total Utility, Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility, Law of Equi Marginal Utility. Demand Analysis: Theory of Demand, Factors Influencing Demand, Elasticity of Demand. Supply Analysis: Supply Schedule and Supply Curve, Factors Influencing Supply.

syllabus.title: Human Resource and Marketing Management
syllabus.topics: Human Resource Management: Meaning and difference between Personnel Management and Human Resource Management, Functions of Human Resource Management. Marketing Management: Concept of Selling And Marketing– Differences, Functions of Marketing, Product Life Cycle, Concept of Advertising, Sales Promotion, Types of Distribution Channels, Marketing Research, Break-Even Analysis.

syllabus.title: Financial Management and Economic Alternatives
syllabus.topics: Financial Management: Functions of Financial Management, Time value of money with cash flow diagrams, Concept of Simple and Compound Interest. Depreciation: Causes, common methods (Straight Line, Declining Balance, Sum of Year’s Digits). Economic Alternatives: Methods of Evaluating Alternatives under Present worth method, Future worth method, Annual Equivalent method.

textbooks: M. Mahajan Industrial Engineering and Production Management Dhanpat Rai Publications 2nd Edition.
Martand Telsang” Industrial & Business Management” S.Chand publications
reference_books: R.Paneer selvam “Production and Operations Management” PHI
Philip Kotler & Gary Armstrong “Principles of Marketing” ,pearson prentice Hall, New Delhi,2012 Edition.
IM Pandey, “Financial Management” Vikas Publications 11th Edition
B.B Mahapatro, “Human Resource Management”,New Age International, 2011

course_outcomes: Understand and aware of themselves and their surroundings(family, society and nature).
Handle problems with sustainable solutions, while keeping human relationships and human nature in mind.
Exhibit critical ability and become sensitive to their commitment towards their understanding of human values, human relationship and human society.
Apply what they have learnt to their own self in different day-to-day settings in real life.

syllabus.title: Course Introduction and Basic Human Aspirations
syllabus.topics: Need, basic guidelines, content and process for value education. Self-exploration, 'Natural acceptance' and experiential validation. Continuous Happiness and Prosperity. Right understanding, Relationship and Physical Facility.

syllabus.title: Understanding Harmony in the Human Being – Harmony in Myself
syllabus.topics: Understanding human being as a co-existence of the sentient ‘I’ and the material ‘Body’. Understanding the needs of Self (‘I’) and ‘Body’. Understanding the harmony of I with the Body: Sanyam and Health; correct appraisal of Physical needs, meaning of Prosperity.

syllabus.title: Understanding Harmony in the Family and Society – Harmony in Human-Human Relationship
syllabus.topics: Understanding values in human-human relationship; meaning of Justice (nine universal values in relationships). Trust and Respect as the foundational values. Understanding the harmony in the society. Resolution, Prosperity, fearlessness (trust) and co-existence as comprehensive Human Goals.

syllabus.title: Understanding Harmony in Nature & Existence – Whole existence as Coexistence
syllabus.topics: Understanding the harmony in the Nature, Inter-connectedness and mutual fulfillment. Understanding Existence as Co-existence. Definitiveness of ethical human conduct. Basis for humanistic education, humanistic constitution and humanistic universal order. Competence in professional ethics.

textbooks: Human values and professional ethics, R. R. Gaur, R. Sangal and G. P. Bagaria, Excel Books Private Limited, New Delhi (2010).
reference_books: JeevanVidya: EkParichaya, A. Nagaraj, JeevanVidya Prakashan, Amarkantak (1999).
Human Values, A. N. Tripathi, New Age International Publishers, New Delhi (2004).
The Story of Stuff: The impact of overconsumption on the planet, our communities, and our health and how we can make it better, Annie Leonard, Free Press, New York (2010).
The story of my experiments with truth: Mahatma Gandhi Autobiography, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, B. N. Publishing (2008).
Small is beautiful: A study of economics as if people mattered, E. F. Schumacher, Vintage Books, London (1993).

course_outcomes: Analyze of propositional calculus and first order logic
Apply the basic and advanced counting techniques
Analyze of relations and digraphs and their applications.
Analyze of graphs and their applications

syllabus.title: Propositional Calculus
syllabus.topics: Fundamentals of Logic: Propositions, Connectives, Truth tables, Tautology, Contradiction, Logical equivalences, Normal forms, Logical inferences, Methods of proof. First Order Predicate Logic: Predicate, Quantifiers, and Rules of inference for Quantified propositions.

syllabus.title: Counting Techniques
syllabus.topics: Basics of Counting: Sum and product rules, Combinations and permutations with and without repetitions. Advanced Counting Techniques: Generating function of sequences, Recurrence relations, Solving recurrence relations.

syllabus.title: Relations and Digraphs
syllabus.topics: Relations and basic graphs, Special properties of binary relations, Equivalence relation, Partially ordered sets, Hasse diagrams, Lattices, Operations on relations, Paths and closures, Directed graphs and Adjacency matrices, Warshall’s algorithm.

syllabus.title: Graph Theory
syllabus.topics: Introduction to graphs, sub graphs, circuits, trees. Sum of degrees theorem, Isomorphism, planar graphs, Euler’s formula, Multi graphs and Euler’s circuits, Hamiltonian graphs, Graph coloring, Chromatic numbers.

textbooks: J. L. Mott, A. Kandel, and T. P. Baker: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Scientists Mathematicians, PHI, 2nd Edition.
reference_books: J. P. Trembly and R. Manohar: Discrete Mathematical structures with applications to computer science, TMH.
K. H. Rosen: Discrete Mathematics and its Applications, Mc Graw Hill Companies, 7th Edition.
D. S. Malik and M. K. Sen: Discrete Mathematical Structures: Theory and applications

course_outcomes: Understand the concepts of database systems.
Analyse the Entity-Relationship models, inturn develop the Relational models that leads to database design.
Apply various normalization techniques to relational models in order to improve database design quality.
Understand database transactions processing, protocols for Concurrency control, Recovery, indexing and storage techniques techniques for database.
Implement database management techniques using relational SQL database to real world applications

syllabus.title: Introduction to Database Systems and SQL
syllabus.topics: Characteristics of Database Approach, Database System Concepts and Architecture, Data Models, Schemas and Instances, Three-schema Architecture, SQL Schema Definition, Data Types, Constraints, Basic and Complex SQL Queries, Insert, Delete, Update statements, Joins, Aggregate functions, Views, Triggers.

syllabus.title: Data Modeling and Relational Algebra
syllabus.topics: Data Modeling Using the Entity-Relationship Model: Entity Types, Attributes, Keys, Relationship types, Weak Entity Types, ER Diagrams, ER-to-Relational Mapping. Relational Data Model and Constraints. Relational Algebra: Unary and Binary Relational Operations (SELECT, PROJECT, JOIN, DIVISION).

syllabus.title: Relational Database Design and Transactions
syllabus.topics: Relational Database Design: Functional Dependencies, Normal Forms (1NF, 2NF, 3NF, BCNF), Properties of Relational Decomposition, Multi-valued Dependencies (4NF, 5NF). Transaction Processing: Introduction, Properties of Transactions (ACID), Serializability, Recoverability.

syllabus.title: Concurrency Control, Recovery, and Indexing
syllabus.topics: Concurrency Control: Lock based, timestamp based, optimistic protocols, Deadlocks. Recovery: Failure Classification, Recovery Concepts, NO-UNDO/REDO techniques, ARIES Algorithm. Indexing Techniques: B+ Trees operations, Hash Based Indexing.

textbooks: Raghu Rama Krishnan,Johannes Gehrke, “Database Management Systems”, 3rd Edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2014 [UNIT 2,3,4]
Abraham Silberschatz, Henry F.Korth, S.Sudarshan, “Database System Concepts”, 7th edition, McGraw-Hill Education,2019 [UNIT 1, 5]
reference_books: Introduction to Database Systems, 8thedition, C J Date, Pearson.
RamezElmasri, Shamkant B. Navathe, “Fundamentals of Database Systems”,7th edition, Pearson Education Ltd, 2016.
Database Principles Fundamentals of Design Implementation and Management, Corlos Coronel, Steven Morris, Peter Robb, Cengage Learning.

course_outcomes: Understand algorithms, including recursive and randomized approaches, asymptotic notations, and the structures, operations, and applications of AVL and B-trees in computing.
Apply heap operations, graph algorithms for search, traversal, and component identification, and divide and conquer techniques for sorting, matrix multiplication, and convex hull problems.
Apply greedy method and dynamic programming techniques to solve different problems.
Apply backtracking and branch and bound techniques to solve different problems and compare P, NP, NP-Hard, and NP-Complete problems.

syllabus.title: Introduction and Advanced Trees
syllabus.topics: Introduction: Algorithms, algorithms as a technology, recursive and randomized algorithms, growth of functions (Asymptotic notations). AVL Trees: Creation, Insertion, Deletion operations and Applications. B-Trees: Creation, Insertion, Deletion operations and Applications.

syllabus.title: Heap Trees, Graphs, and Divide and Conquer
syllabus.topics: Heap Trees (Priority Queues): Min and Max Heaps, Operations and Applications. Graphs: Terminology, Representations, Basic Search and Traversals, Connected Components and Biconnected Components, applications. Divide and Conquer: The General Method, Quick Sort, Merge Sort, Strassen’s matrix multiplication, Convex Hull.

syllabus.title: Greedy Method and Dynamic Programming
syllabus.topics: Greedy Method: General Method, Job Sequencing with deadlines, Knapsack Problem, Minimum cost spanning trees, Single Source Shortest Paths. Dynamic Programming: General Method, All pairs shortest paths, Single Source Shortest Paths– General Weights (Bellman Ford Algorithm), Optimal Binary Search Trees, 0/1 Knapsack, String Editing, Travelling Salesperson problem.

syllabus.title: Backtracking, Branch and Bound, and NP Problems
syllabus.topics: Backtracking: General Method, 8-Queens Problem, Sum of Subsets problem, Graph Coloring, 0/1 Knapsack Problem. Branch and Bound: The General Method, 0/1 Knapsack Problem, Travelling Salesperson problem. NP Hard and NP Complete Problems: Basic Concepts, Cook’s theorem, NP Hard Graph Problems, NP Hard Scheduling Problems.

textbooks: Fundamentals of Data Structures in C++, Horowitz, Ellis; Sahni, Sartaj; Mehta, Dinesh, 2nd Edition Universities Press [Unit 1, 2]
Computer Algorithms in C++,Ellis Horowitz, Sartaj Sahni, Sanguthevar Rajasekaran, 2nd Edition University Press [Unit 2, 3, 4]
reference_books: Data Structures and program design in C, Robert Kruse, Pearson Education Asia
An introduction to Data Structures with applications, Trembley & Sorenson, McGraw Hill

course_outcomes: Understand the basic concepts of object oriented programming.
Apply multiple inheritance through interfaces for a given application.
Apply exceptions, thread capabilities and handling files on a given application.
Apply functional programming and Collections framework for a given application.

syllabus.title: Java Fundamentals and OOP Concepts
syllabus.topics: Object Oriented Programming concepts, Java introduction and features, Data Types, Variables, Operators, Control Statements. Introducing Classes and Objects: constructors, 'this' keyword, garbage collection, method overloading, static and final keywords, nested classes.

syllabus.title: Inheritance, Interfaces, and Packages
syllabus.topics: String Handling in Java. Inheritance: Types, 'super' keyword, method overriding, abstract classes. Interfaces: Declaration, implementation, multiple interfaces, default and static methods. Packages and Java Library: Defining and importing packages, java.lang, java.util classes.

syllabus.title: Exception Handling, I/O, and Multithreading
syllabus.topics: Exception handling: try, catch, finally, throw, throws, checked and unchecked exceptions. Java I/O and File: I/O API, Byte streams, Character streams, Scanner class. Multithread Programming: Thread Class, thread states, priority, synchronization, inter-thread communication.

syllabus.title: Functional Programming and Collections
syllabus.topics: Pragmatic Functional Programming using Lambdas: Functional Interfaces, Lambda Expressions, Method References. Collections Framework: Collection, List, Set interfaces. ArrayList, LinkedList, HashSet classes. Map Classes: HashMap, TreeMap. The Stream API: Stream basics, reduction operations, parallel streams, mapping, collecting.

textbooks: Herbert Schildt, “Java The Complete Reference”, Eleventh Edition, Oracle Press, 2019.
JAVA one step ahead, Anitha Seth, B.L.Juneja, Oxford.
reference_books: Herbert Schildt, Dale Skrien, “Java Fundamentals A Comprehension Introduction”, Special Indian Edition, McGraw-Hill Education India Pvt. Ltd, 2017.
Joywith JAVA,Fundamentals of Object Oriented Programming, DebasisSamanta, MonalisaSarma, Cambridge, 2023.
JAVA 9 for Programmers, Paul Deitel, Harvey Deitel, 4th Edition, Pearson.
Paul J. Dietel and Dr.Harvey M. Deitel, “Java How to Program”, Eleventh Edition, Deitel & Associates, Inc.l , 2018.

course_outcomes: Think reason logically in any critical situation.
Analyze given information to find correct solution.
To reduce the mistakes in day to day activities in practical life.
Develop time management skills by approaching different shortcut methods.
Use mathematical based reasoning to make decisions.
Apply logical thinking to solve problems and puzzles in qualifying exams for companies and in other competitive exams.

syllabus.title: Analytical Reasoning
syllabus.topics: Series Completion, Coding-Decoding, Blood Relation, Puzzles test.

syllabus.title: Logical Reasoning
syllabus.topics: Direction sense test, Logical Venn diagrams, Number test, ranking test, Mathematical operations.

syllabus.title: Abstract Reasoning
syllabus.topics: Arithmetical Reasoning, Inserting missing character, Syllogism.

syllabus.title: Non–Verbal Reasoning
syllabus.topics: Water images, Mirror images, Paper folding, Paper cutting, Embedded Figures, Dot situation, Cubes & Dice.

textbooks: R. S. Aggarwal, “ Verbal and non-verbal reasoning”, Revised Edition, S Chand publication, 2017 ISBN:81-219-0551-6

course_outcomes: Understand the python syntax and semantics of control flow statements
Apply functions, modules and string handling in Python to solve problems
Analyze the methods to create and manipulate programs with Python data structures
Analyse the concepts of object oriented approach to solve problems

syllabus.title: Python Basics, Control Flow, Functions, and Strings
syllabus.topics: History, Identifiers, Keywords, Variables, Operators, Data Types, Control Flow Statements (if, while, for), Functions (built-in, user-defined, arguments), Strings (creation, operations, slicing, methods).

syllabus.title: Python Data Structures
syllabus.topics: Lists (creation, operations, indexing, slicing, methods), Dictionaries (creation, accessing, methods), Tuples (creation, operations, indexing), Sets (creation, methods, frozenset).

syllabus.title: Files and Object-Oriented Programming
syllabus.topics: Files (text, binary, pickle, CSV), os and os.path modules. Object-Oriented Programming: Classes and Objects, Constructors, Encapsulation, Inheritance, Polymorphism.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Data Science Libraries
syllabus.topics: Functional Programming, JSON and XML in Python, NumPy with Python, Pandas.

textbooks: ReemaThareja,“Python ProgrammingUsing Problem Solving Approach”, Oxford University Press, 2019.

metadata.course_name: Advanced Data Structures and Algorithms Lab
course_outcomes: Implement efficient binary trees, M-way search trees, graph traversal and shortest path algorithms.
Use divide and conquer, and greedy methods for implementing solutions for problems.
Implement solutions for problems using dynamic programming and backtracking.
Apply Branch and Bound techniques to write programs for different problems.

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: Task 1: Construct an AVL tree and implement insert/delete operations.
Task 2: Construct a B-Tree and implement search, insert, delete operations.
Task 3: Construct Min and Max Heaps and implement deletion.
Task 4: Implement BFT and DFT for a graph represented by Adjacency Matrix and Adjacency Lists.
Task 5: Find bi-connected components in a given graph.
Task 6: Implement Quick sort and Merge sort and observe execution time.
Task 7: Compare performance of Single Source Shortest Paths using Greedy method.
Task 8: Implement Job sequencing with deadlines using Greedy strategy.
Task 9: Solve 0/1 Knapsack problem Using Dynamic Programming.
Task 10: Implement N-Queens Problem Using Backtracking.
Task 11: Use Backtracking strategy to solve 0/1 Knapsack problem.
Task 12: Implement Travelling Sales Person problem using Branch and Bound approach.

textbooks: T.H.Cormen,C.E.Leiserson, R.L.Rivest and C.Stein, “Introduction to Algorithms”, 2/e, PHI Pvt. Ltd., Pearson Education, 2009.
Ellis Horowitz, SatrajSahni and Rajasekharan, “Fundamentals of Computer Algorithms”, Galgotia Publications Pvt. Ltd, 2008.

ComputerAlgorithms/C++Ellis Horowitz, Sartaj Sahni, Sanguthevar Rajasekaran, 2nd Edition, University Press

metadata.course_name: Object Oriented Programming Through Java Lab
course_outcomes: Design solutions to applications using object oriented approach using Java.
Implement java technology to solve runtime errors and test the correctness of programs using exception handling and assertions.
Develop java applications to make use of I/O Streams and multithreading to solve real world problems.
Solve real world problems using Collections framework.

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: Apply fundamentals of Java Data types, Variables, Operators, and Control Statements.
Task 2: Apply the concepts of Classes and Objects.
Task 3: Apply the concepts of Arrays.
Task 4: Apply the concepts of String and String Tokenizer classes.
Task 5: Apply the concepts of Inheritance and types of Inheritance.
Task 6: Apply the concepts of Method Overloading and Method Overriding.
Task 7: Apply the concepts of Packages.
Task 8: Apply the concepts of Interfaces.
Task 9: Apply the concepts of Exception Handling.
Task 10: Develop a Java application to copy content from one file to another using I/O Streams.
Task 11: Apply the concepts of Threads and Multithreading.
Task 12: Design an Employee Database application with JDBC to perform Insert, Select, and Delete operations.

course_outcomes: Analyze probability distributions with random variables
Apply knowledge of Continuous Random Variables and Probability Densities
Apply random phenomena of sample to test the Hypothesis concerning means
Analyze random phenomena of sample to test the hypothesis concerning variances and regression

syllabus.title: Probability Theory and Distributions
syllabus.topics: Probability Theory: Sample Spaces and events, Counting, Probability, Conditional Probability, Bayes’ Theorem. Probability Distributions: Random Variables (discrete and continuous), Expectation, Variance, Binomial distribution, Poisson distribution.

syllabus.title: Probability Densities
syllabus.topics: Continuous random variables, The Normal Distribution, The Normal approximation to the Binomial Distribution. Other Probability Densities: The Uniform Distribution, The Log Normal Distribution, The Gamma Distribution, The Beta Distribution, The Weibull distribution.

syllabus.title: Sampling Distributions and Inferences Concerning Mean
syllabus.topics: Sampling Distributions: Populations and Samples. Inferences Concerning Mean: Point Estimation, Interval Estimation. Test of Hypothesis: Null Hypothesis, Hypothesis concerning one mean, Hypothesis concerning two means.

syllabus.title: Inferences Concerning Variances and Regression
syllabus.topics: Inferences Concerning Variances: Estimation of variances, Hypothesis concerning one variance, Hypothesis concerning two variances. Regression Analysis: The method of least squares, Multiple Regression, Correlation, Karl Pearson’s coefficient of correlation.

textbooks: Johnson, R. A. (2011). Probability and statistics for engineers (8th ed.). Prentice Hall India Learning Private Limited.
reference_books: Walpole, R. E., Myers, R. H., Myers, S. L., Ye, K. (1993). Probability and statistics for engineers and scientists (Vol. 5). New York: Macmillan
Biswal, P. C.(2007). Probability and statistics. Prentice Hall India Learning Private Limited.
Iyengar, T. K. V., Gandhi, B. K., Ranganadham, S., Prasad, M. V. S. S. N.(2008). Probability and statistics. S. Chand Publishing.

metadata.prerequisites: 23AI&DS3305 Advanced Data Structures and Algorithms Analysis
course_outcomes: Understand the AI agents for problem solving
Understand AI solutions using Heuristic and Pruning approaches
Apply various knowledge representation techniques
Apply the logic concepts and learnings to Expert Systems

syllabus.title: Introduction to AI and Problem Solving
syllabus.topics: AI problems, foundation and history of AI. Intelligent agents: Agents and Environments, rationality, nature of environments, structure of agents. Problem solving agents: Well defined problems and Solutions, problem formulation, Example problems (8-puzzle, Water jug).

syllabus.title: Search Techniques
syllabus.topics: Searching for solutions, uniformed search strategies (Breadth first, depth first). Heuristic Search: Informed search strategies, Hill climbing, Best First search, A* Algorithm, AO* Algorithms. Adversarial Search: Games, mini-max algorithm, Alpha-Beta pruning, Evaluation functions.

syllabus.title: Knowledge Representation
syllabus.topics: Weak Slot and filler structures, Semantic nets, frames. Representing knowledge using rules: Procedural versus declarative knowledge, Logic programming, Forward vs Backward reasoning. Knowledge Representation Issues: Representation and mapping, Reasoning under uncertainty.

syllabus.title: Logic, Learning, and Expert Systems
syllabus.topics: Logic concepts: Predicate Logic, Propositional vs. Predicate Logic, unification, Resolution. Learning: Learning from observation, Explanation based learning, Statistical Learning, Reinforcement Learning. Expert Systems: Architecture, Roles, Knowledge Acquisition, Typical expert systems (MYCIN, DART).

textbooks: S. Russel and P. Norvig, “Artificial Intelligence– A Modern Approach”, SecondEdition, Pearson Education.
Kevin Night and Elaine Rich, Nair B., “Artificial Intelligence (SIE)”, Mc Graw Hill
reference_books: David Poole, Alan Mackworth, Randy Goebel,”Computational Intelligence: a logical approach”, Oxford University Press.
G. Luger, “Artificial Intelligence: Structures and Strategies for complex problemsolving”, Fourth Edition, Pearson Education.
J. Nilsson, “Artificial Intelligence: A new Synthesis”, Elsevier Publishers.
Artificial Intelligence, SarojKaushik, CENGAGE Learning.

course_outcomes: Understand the significance of Data Science
Analyze large data and apply NoSql for handling Bigdata
Apply Data Analytics tools for various data science applications
Apply Visualization and Development tools for data

syllabus.title: Introduction to Data Science and Machine Learning
syllabus.topics: Introduction to Data science, benefits and uses, facets of data, data science process. Data Science process: Overview, defining goals, retrieving data, cleansing, integrating and transforming data, exploratory analysis, model building, presenting findings. Applications of machine learning in Data science, role of ML in DS, Python tools, modelling process, types of ML.

syllabus.title: Handling Large Data and NoSQL
syllabus.topics: Handling large data: problems and general techniques. NoSQL movement for handling Bigdata: Distributing data storage and processing with Hadoop, ACID principle, CAP theorem, BASE principle of NoSQL, types of NoSQL databases.

syllabus.title: Tools and Applications of Data Science
syllabus.topics: Introducing Neo4j for dealing with graph databases, graph query language Cypher, Applications of graph databases, Python libraries like nltk and SQLite for handling Text mining and analytics, case study on classifying Reddit posts.

syllabus.title: Data Visualization and Application Development
syllabus.topics: Data Visualization options, Crossfilter, the JavaScript MapReduce library, Creating an interactive dashboard with dc.js, Dashboard development tools. Applying the Data Science process for real world problem solving scenarios as a detailed case study.

textbooks: Davy Cielen, Arno D.B.Meysman, and Mohamed Ali, “Introducing to Data Science using Python tools”, Manning Publications Co, Dreamtech press, 2016.
Prateek Gupta, “Data Science with Jupyter” BPB publishers, 2019 for basics
reference_books: Joel Grus, “Data Science From Scratch”, OReilly, 2019.
Doing Data Science: Straight Talk From The Frontline, 1 st Edition, Cathy O’Neil and Rachel Schutt, O’Reilly, 2013.

course_outcomes: Understand digital logic principles and basic structure of a computer
Apply concepts of combinational and sequential logic to design digital circuits
Apply algorithms to perform arithmetic operations on fixed point and floating point data
Understand Processor, Memory and I/O organization of basic computer

syllabus.title: Data Representation and Digital Logic Circuits-1
syllabus.topics: Data Representation: Binary Numbers, Fixed Point Representation, Floating Point Representation, Number base conversions, Octal and Hexadecimal Numbers, Signed binary numbers, Binary codes. Digital Logic Circuits-1: Basic Logic Functions, Logic gates, universal logic gates, Minimization of Logic expressions, K-Map Simplification, Combinational Circuits, Decoders, Multiplexers.

syllabus.title: Digital Logic Circuits-2 and Basic Computer Structure
syllabus.topics: Digital Logic Circuits-2: Sequential Circuits, Flip-Flops, Binary counters, Registers, Shift Registers, Ripple counters. Basic Structure of Computers: Computer Types, Functional units, Basic operational concepts, Bus structures, Software, Performance, multiprocessors and multi computers, Von- Neumann Architecture.

syllabus.title: Computer Arithmetic and Processor Organization
syllabus.topics: Computer Arithmetic: Addition and Subtraction of Signed Numbers, Design of Fast Adders, Multiplication of Positive Numbers, Signed-operand Multiplication, Fast Multiplication, Integer Division, Floating-Point Numbers and Operations. Processor Organization: Fundamental Concepts, Execution of a Complete Instruction, Multiple-Bus Organization, Hardwired Control and Multi programmed Control.

syllabus.title: Memory and I/O Organization
syllabus.topics: The Memory Organization: Basic Concepts, Semiconductor RAM Memories, Read-Only Memories, Cache Memories, Performance Consideration, Virtual Memories, Memory Management, Secondary Storage. Input/Output Organization: Accessing I/O Devices, Interrupts, Direct Memory Access, Buses, Interface Circuits, Standard I/O Interfaces.

textbooks: Morris Mano, Digital Logic and Computer Design, Pearson Education, 16th Impression, 2016.
Carl Hamacher, Zvonko Vranesic, Safwat Zaky, Computer Organization, Mc Graw Hill, 5th Edition, 2014.
William Stallings, Computer Organization and Architecture, Pearson Education, 11th Edition, 2012.

Design, David A. Paterson, John L. Hennessy, Elsevier, Computer Organization and 2nd Edition, 2010.
Roth, Fundamentals of Logic Design, Thomson, 5th Edition, 2014.

Identify various ecosystem and need for biodiversity

syllabus.title: Multidisciplinary Nature of Environmental Studies and Natural Resources

syllabus.title: Ecosystems and Biodiversity
syllabus.topics: Ecosystems: Concept, structure, and function. Energy flow, food chains, food webs. Types of ecosystems. Biodiversity and Its Conservation: Genetic, species, and ecosystem diversity. Value, threats, and conservation of biodiversity.

syllabus.title: Environmental Pollution and Disaster Management
syllabus.topics: Definition, causes, effects, and control measures of Air, Water, Soil, Marine, Noise, Thermal pollution, and Nuclear hazards. Solid waste management. Disaster management: Floods, earthquake, cyclone, and landslides.

syllabus.title: Social Issues and the Environment

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: Creating a NumPy Array (basic, zeros, ones, random, identity, evenly spaced).
Task 2: Shape and Reshaping of NumPy Array (dimensions, shape, size, reshape, flatten, transpose).
Task 3: Expanding, Squeezing, and Sorting a NumPy Array.
Task 4: Indexing and Slicing of 1-D, 2-D, and 3-D NumPy Arrays.
Task 5: Stacking and Concatenating Numpy Arrays.

course_outcomes: Understand fundamental concepts of and techniques of data warehousing and data mining.
Apply various pre-processing techniques in Data mining.
Analyze classification and apriori algorithms to solve real life problems.
Analyze different types of clustering algorithms to solve real life problems.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Data Warehousing and Data Mining
syllabus.topics: Data Warehousing and OLAP: Basic concepts, Data Cube, Data Warehouse Design and Implementation. Introduction to Data Mining, Technologies, and Applications. Getting to Know your data: Data Objects and Attributes, Statistical Descriptions, Visualization, Measuring Similarity and Dissimilarity.

syllabus.title: Data Preprocessing
syllabus.topics: Overview of Data Preprocessing. Data Cleaning: Missing Values, Noisy data. Data Integration: Entity Identification, Redundancy and Correlation Analysis. Data Reduction: Wavelet Transformation, Principal Components Analysis, Attribute Subset selection. Data Transformation and Discretization: Normalization, Binning.

syllabus.title: Association Analysis and Classification
syllabus.topics: Association Analysis: Frequent Itemset Generation, Rule Generation, Apriori Algorithm, FP-Growth Algorithm. Classification: Basic Concepts, Decision Tree Induction, Attribute Selection Measures, Tree Pruning, Visual Mining for Decision Trees.

syllabus.title: Cluster Analysis
syllabus.topics: Overview of Cluster Analysis, Clustering techniques. K-means: Basic Algorithm, Additional Issues, Bi-secting K-Means. Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering. DBSCAN: Density-Based Approach, Algorithm, Strengths and Weaknesses.

textbooks: Jiawei Han, Michel Kamber, Data Mining concepts and Techniques, 3rd edition, Elsevier, 2011.

Apply models based on Decision trees and Bayes rule.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Machine Learning and Nearest Neighbor Models
syllabus.topics: Evolution of Machine Learning, Paradigms for ML, Stages in Machine Learning. Nearest Neighbor-Based Models: Proximity Measures, Distance Measures, KNN Classifier, KNN Regression, Performance Evaluation.

syllabus.title: Decision Trees and Bayes Classifier
syllabus.topics: Models Based on Decision Trees: Decision Trees for Classification, Impurity Measures, Regression Based on Decision Trees, Bias–Variance Trade-off, Random Forests. The Bayes Classifier: Bayes’ Rule and Inference, Optimality, Multi-Class Classification, Naive Bayes Classifier (NBC).

syllabus.title: Linear Discriminants for Machine Learning
syllabus.topics: Linear Discriminants for Classification, Perceptron Classifier and Learning Algorithm, Support Vector Machines (SVM), Linearly Non-Separable Case, Kernel Trick, Logistic Regression, Linear Regression, Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs), Backpropagation.

course_outcomes: Understand the basic components of an Operating System.
Apply CPU Scheduling techniques and mechanisms used for process synchronization.
Analyse Memory management techniques and methods for handling deadlocks.
Analyse File system Implementation techniques and protection mechanisms.

syllabus.title: System Structures, Processes, and Threads
syllabus.topics: Operating System Services, System Calls, OS Design and Implementation, OS Structure. Processes: Process Concept, Scheduling, Operations, IPC. Threads and Concurrency: Multithreading models, Thread libraries, Threading issues.

syllabus.title: CPU Scheduling and Synchronization
syllabus.topics: CPU Scheduling: Basic concepts, Scheduling criteria, Scheduling algorithms, multiple processor scheduling. Synchronization Tools: The Critical Section Problem, Peterson’s Solution, Mutex Locks, Semaphores, Monitors, Classic problems of Synchronization.

syllabus.title: Deadlocks and Memory Management
syllabus.topics: Deadlocks: System Model, Characterization, Methods for handling (Prevention, Avoidance, Detection, Recovery). Memory-Management Strategies: Contiguous memory allocation, Paging, Page Table Structure, Swapping. Virtual Memory Management: Demand paging, Page replacement, Thrashing.

syllabus.topics: The Nature of Software, Software Engineering Practice. The Software Process: Generic Process Model, Process Assessment. Process models: Prescriptive, Specialized, Unified, Personal and Team Process Models. Agile Development: Agility, Extreme Programming (XP), Other Agile Models.

Analyze a variety of approaches for building recommender systems
Apply system evaluation methods from both algorithmic and users perspectives
Apply applications of recommender systems in various domains

syllabus.title: Introduction and Collaborative Filtering
syllabus.topics: Recommender system functions, Linear Algebra review, Applications and issues. Collaborative Filtering: User-based nearest neighbor, Item-based nearest neighbor, Model-based approaches, Attacks on collaborative systems.

syllabus.title: Content-Based and Knowledge-Based Recommendation
syllabus.topics: Content-based recommendation: High-level architecture, Item profiles, Feature discovery, Learning user profiles, Similarity-based retrieval. Knowledge-based recommendation: Knowledge representation, Constraint-based recommenders, Case-based recommenders.
