syllabus.topics: Opportunities for hybridization. Monolithic design: Feature combination, Feature augmentation. Parallelized design: Weighted, Switching, Mixed. Pipelined design: Cascade, Meta-level. Limitations of hybridization.

syllabus.title: Evaluation and Advanced Topics
syllabus.topics: Evaluating Recommender System: Evaluation designs, Historical datasets, Error metrics, Decision-Support metrics, User-Centered metrics. Recommender Systems and communities: Personalized web search, Social tagging systems, Trust and recommendations.

textbooks: Jannach D., Zanker M. and FelFering A., Recommender Systems: An Introduction, Cambridge University Press, 1st edition, 2011.
Ricci F., Rokach L., Shapira D., Kantor B.P., Recommender Systems Handbook, Springer, 1st edition, 2011.
reference_books: Manouselis N., Drachsler H., Verbert K., Duval E., Recommender Systems For Learning, Springer, 1st edition, 2013.

course_outcomes: Understand the overview of information Retrieval
Apply different techniques for compression of an index including the dictionary and its posting list
Apply appropriate method for text classification or clustering
Understand the basics of web search

syllabus.title: Fundamentals of Information Retrieval
syllabus.topics: Boolean retrieval, term vocabulary, postings lists, dictionaries, tolerant retrieval, index construction and compression. Scoring, term weighting, vector space model. Relevance feedback and query expansion. Probabilistic information retrieval and Language models.

syllabus.title: Text Classification
syllabus.topics: The text classification problem, Naive Bayes text classification, Bernoulli model, Feature selection, Evaluation of text classification. Vector space classification: Rocchio classification, k nearest neighbour, Linear versus nonlinear classifiers. Support vector machines (SVM).

syllabus.title: Text Clustering and Latent Semantic Indexing
syllabus.topics: Flat clustering: K-means, Model-based clustering. Hierarchical clustering: Hierarchical agglomerative clustering (single-link, complete-link, group-average), Divisive clustering. Matrix decompositions and latent semantic indexing: Singular value decompositions, Low-rank approximations.

syllabus.title: Web Information Retrieval
syllabus.topics: Web search basics: Web characteristics, Index size estimation, Near duplicates and shingling. Web Crawling and Indexes: Crawling, Distributing Indexes. Link Analysis: Web as a graph, PageRank, Hubs and authorities.

textbooks: Christopher D. Manning, PrabhakarRaghavan, HinrichSch¨utze, “An Introduction to Information Retrieval”, Cambridge University Press,2008.
reference_books: Stefan B¨uttcher, Charles L, A. Clarke, Gordon V. Cormack, “Information Retrieval: Implementing and evaluating search engines”, MIT Press, 2010
David A.Grossman, OphirFrieder, “Information Retrieval: Algorithms and Heuristics”, Springer, 2004
Frakes, “Information Retrieval: Data Structures and Algorithms”, Pearson, 2009

course_outcomes: Apply exploratory data analysis techniques using statistical and visualization tools to interpret and present different types of data effectively.
Apply data transformation techniques to prepare, analyze, and interpret datasets.
Apply descriptive statistical methods and grouping techniques to analyze and organize datasets effectively.
Analyze data using correlation and multivariate techniques and examine patterns in time series data.

syllabus.title: EDA Fundamentals and Visualization
syllabus.topics: Understanding data science, significance of EDA, Numerical and Categorical data. Software tools (NumPy, Pandas, SciPy, Matplotlib). Visual Aids for EDA: Line chart, Bar charts, Scatter plot, Area plot, Pie chart, Histogram.

syllabus.title: Data Transformation
syllabus.topics: EDA with Personal Email: Data cleansing, loading CSV, converting dates, removing NaN values. Data transformation techniques: Merging data frames, data deduplication, replacing values, handling missing data, renaming indexes, discretization and binning, outlier detection.

syllabus.title: Descriptive Statistics and Grouping
syllabus.topics: Descriptive Statistics: Distribution function, cumulative distribution function, Measures of central tendency (Mean, Median, Mode), Measures of dispersion (Standard deviation, Variance, Skewness, Kurtosis), percentiles, quartiles. Grouping Datasets: Understanding groupby(), data aggregation, pivot tables, cross-tabulations.

syllabus.title: Correlation and Time Series Analysis
syllabus.topics: Correlation: Univariate, bivariate, and multivariate analysis. Simpson’s paradox. Time Series Analysis: Fundamentals of TSA, characteristics of time series data. TSA with Open Power System Data: Data cleaning, time-based indexing, visualizing, grouping, and resampling time series data.

textbooks: Suresh Kumar Mukhiya, Usman Ahmed, Hands-On Exploratory Data Analysis with Python, Packt Publishing, 1st Edition, 2020.
reference_books: Ronald K. Pearson, Exploratory Data Analysis Using R, CRC Press, 1st Edition, 2020.
Radhika Datar, Harish Garg, Hands-On Exploratory Data Analysis with R: Become an expert in exploratory data analysis using R packages, 1st Edition, Packt Publishing, 2019.

course_outcomes: Understand the concepts of Web designing.
Apply the concepts of HTML5 and CSS to design static web pages.
Apply client side technologies to design interactive Web interfaces
Apply interactive server side scripting for a web application.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Web and Web Design
syllabus.topics: Concept of WWW, Internet, HTTP Protocol, Web browser and servers, Web 2.0. Web Design: Concepts of effective web design, issues (Browser, Bandwidth, Cache), Page Layout, User centric design, Sitemap, Planning and publishing.

syllabus.title: HTML and CSS
syllabus.topics: HTML: Basics, formatting, fonts, comments, color, hyperlinks, lists, tables, images, forms, XHTML, Meta tags, frames. Overview of HTML5. Style sheets: Need for CSS, syntax, using CSS, backgrounds, text, fonts, borders, boxes, margins, padding, positioning. Overview of CSS3.

syllabus.title: JavaScript and XML
syllabus.topics: JavaScript: Client side scripting, variables, functions, conditions, loops, Pop up boxes. Advance JavaScript: Objects, DOM manipulation, forms and validations. DHTML. XML: Introduction, uses, key components, DTD and Schemas. Transforming XML using XSL and XSLT.

syllabus.title: PHP and MySQL
syllabus.topics: PHP: Syntax, decision and looping, PHP and HTML, Arrays, Functions, Form processing, Files, Cookies and Sessions, Object Oriented Programming with PHP. PHP and MySQL: Connection to server, creating/selecting database, creating table, inserting data, queries, deleting data. phpMyAdmin.

textbooks: R. Moseley and M. T. Savaliya, Developing Web Applications, 2nd ed. New Delhi, India: Wiley India Pvt. Ltd., 2011.
reference_books: J. Sklar, Web Design Principles, 5th edition, Boston, MA: Course Technology Cengage Learning, 2012.
H. M. Deitel, P. J. Deitel, and T. R. Nieto, Internet & World Wide Web: How to Program, 3rd edition, Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson/Prentice Hall, 2004.
B. M. Harwani, Developing Web Applications in PHP and AJAX. New Delhi, India: Tata McGraw-Hill Education, 2010.

course_outcomes: Understand the design concepts and applications of Internet of Things
Understand Standards and Key Technologies in IoT.
Apply the steps of the design methodology in developing IoT applications using Raspberry Pi
Understand the Privacy, security and Vulnerabilities of internet of Things

syllabus.title: Introduction to Internet of Things
syllabus.topics: Introduction, Physical design of IoT, Logical Design of IoT, IoT Enabling technologies, IoT levels & Deployment templates. Domain Specific IoTs– Home Automation, Cities, Environment, Energy, Retail, Logistics, Agriculture, Industry, Health and Lifestyle.

syllabus.title: IoT, M2M, and Design Methodology
syllabus.topics: Introduction, M2M, Difference between IoT and M2M, SDN and NFV for IoT. IoT Platforms Design Methodology: Introduction, IoT Design Methodology, Case Study on IoT System for Home Automation and Weather Monitoring.

syllabus.title: IoT Physical Devices and Endpoints
syllabus.topics: Basic building blocks of an IoT Device, Introduction to Raspberry Pi Board, Linux on Raspberry Pi, Raspberry Pi Interfaces (serial, SPI, I2C). Programming Raspberry PI with Python– Controlling LED, Interfacing LED and Switch, Interfacing a Light sensor (LDR).

syllabus.title: IoT Privacy, Security and Vulnerabilities
syllabus.topics: Introduction, Vulnerabilities, Security Requirements and Threat Analysis. Privacy, Security Requirements, Use Cases and Misuse Cases, IoT Security Tomography and Layered Attacker model. Security models, profiles and protocols for IoT.

textbooks: Arshdeep Bahga , Vijay Madisetti, Internet of Things (A Hands-on Approach), 1st Edition, Universities Press Private Limited, 2014.
Raj Kamal, Internet of Things, Architecture and Design Principles, 1st Edition, McGraw Hill Education Private Limited, 2017.
reference_books: Matt Richardson & Shawn Wallace, Getting Started with Raspberry Pi, O’Reilly (SPD), 2014.
David Hanes, IOT Fundamentals, 1st Edition, CISCO Press, 2018.

course_outcomes: Understand the fundamentals of Android Operating System.
Apply UI principles to develop interfaces for Android platform.
Apply mobile application concepts to deploy and publish a given app into android device.
Apply principles to develop a database connection for a given mobile application.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Android
syllabus.topics: Open platform for mobile development, Native android applications, Android SDK Features, Development Framework, Creating your First Application. Creating Applications and Activities: Application Manifest File, Externalizing Resources, The Android Application Lifecycle.

syllabus.title: Building User Interfaces
syllabus.topics: Fundamental Android UI Design, UI fundamentals, Introducing Layouts. User Interface (UI) Components: TextViews, Buttons, Radio Buttons, Checkboxes, Spinners, Dialogs and pickers. Event Handling: Handling clicks or changes of various UI components.

syllabus.title: Fragments, Adapters, and Intents
syllabus.topics: Introducing Fragments: Creating Fragments, Fragment Lifecycle, Fragment Manager. Introducing Adapters: Native Adapters, Customizing Adapters. Introducing Intents: Using intents to launch activities, Using Intents to broadcast Events, Notifications, Toasts.

syllabus.title: Intent Filters and Databases
syllabus.topics: Creating Intent Filters and Broadcast Receivers: Using Intent Filters to Service Implicit Intents. Working with SQLite Databases: SQLiteOpenHelper, Opening and Creating Databases, Android Database design considerations, Querying a Database, Adding, Updating and Removing Rows.

textbooks: R. Meier, Professional Android 4 Application Development, 3rd ed. Indianapolis, IN, USA: Wiley India (Wrox), 2012.
reference_books: D. Griffiths and D. Griffiths, Head First Android Development: A Brain-Friendly Guide, 2nd ed. Sebastopol, CA, USA: O’Reilly Media, Inc., 2017.
J. C. Sheusi, Android Application Development for Java Programmers. Boston, MA, USA: Cengage Learning, 2013.
W.-M. Lee, Beginning Android 4 Application Development. Indianapolis, IN, USA: Wiley India (Wrox), 2012.
B. Phillips, C. Stewart, B. Hardy, and K. Marsicano, Android Programming: The Big Nerd Ranch Guide, 3rd ed. Atlanta, GA, USA: Big Nerd Ranch LLC, 2017.

metadata.course_name: Data Warehousing and Machine Learning Lab
course_outcomes: Apply techniques of data warehousing and data mining.
Apply various pre-processing techniques on datasets using Data mining techniques.
Analyze classification and apriori algorithms to solve real life problems.
Analyze different types of clustering algorithms to solve real life problems.

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: Creation of a Data Warehouse (Build DW/Data Mart, design schemas, write ETL scripts, perform OLAP operations).
Task 2: Explore machine learning tool 'WEKA' (Interface, options, arff file format, load datasets).
Task 3: Perform data preprocessing and association rule mining (Apriori) on data sets.
Task 4: Demonstrate performing classification (ID3, J48, Naive-Bayes, k-NN) on data sets.
Task 5: Demonstrate performing clustering (k-means) on data sets.
Task 6: Demonstrate knowledge flow application in Weka/R.
Task 7-16: Implement various data mining and ML algorithms (ZeroR, Apriori, Naive Bayesian, k-means) and techniques (chi-square, dissimilarity matrix, visualization) using Java/Python/R.

textbooks: Jiawei Han, Michel Kamber, Data Mining concepts and Techniques, 3rd edition, Elsevier, 2011.
Pang-Ning Tan & Michael Steinbach, Vipin Kumar, Introduction to Data Mining, 2nd edition, Pearson, 2012.
reference_books: VikramPudi and P. Radha Krishna, Data Mining, 1st Edition, Oxford Publisher.
Arun K Pujari, Data Mining Techniques, 3rd edition, Universities Press, 2013.

course_outcomes: Implement UNIX concepts for creation of Shell Scripts
Apply CPU Scheduling algorithms, page replacement algorithms, thread implementation
Analyze Bankers Algorithm for Dead Lock avoidance and process Synchronization
Analyze the memory management techniques

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: Practicing of Basic UNIX Commands.
Task 2: Programs using UNIX operating system calls (fork, exec, getpid, exit, wait).
Task 3: Simulate UNIX commands like cp, ls, grep.
Task 4: Simulate CPU scheduling algorithms (FCFS, SJF, Priority, Round Robin).
Task 5: Control port access using Semaphores and Monitors.
Task 6: Illustrate concurrent execution of threads using pthreads.
Task 7: Solve producer-consumer problem using Semaphores.
Task 8: Implement memory allocation methods (First fit, Worst fit, Best fit).
Task 9: Simulate page replacement algorithms (FIFO, LRU, LFU).
Task 10: Simulate Paging Technique of memory management.
Task 11: Implement Bankers Algorithm for Dead Lock avoidance.
Task 12: Simulate file allocation strategies (Sequential, Indexed, Linked).

reference_books: Silberschatz A, Galvin P B, Gagne G, Operating System Concepts, Wiley, 10th Edition, 2018.
Tanenbaum A S, Modern Operating Systems, Galgotia Publications Pvt. Ltd, 4th Edition, 2016.
Stallings W, Operating Systems-Internals and Design Principles, Pearson, 9th Edition, 2018.
D.M Dhamdhere, Operating Systems: A Concept Based Approach, McGraw- Hill, 3rd Edition, 2013.

course_outcomes: Implement router, template engine and authentication using sessions to develop application in ExpressJS.
Build a single page application using RESTful APIs in ExpressJS
Apply router and hooksin designing ReactJS application
Implement MongoDB queries to perform CRUD operations on document database

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: 1. ExpressJS: Routing, HTTP Methods, Middleware.
2. ExpressJS: Templating, Form Data.
3. ExpressJS: Cookies, Sessions, Authentication.
4. ExpressJS: Database connection (MongoDB) and RESTful APIs.
5. ReactJS: Render HTML, JSX, Function & Class Components.
6. ReactJS: Props, States, Styles, and Event Handling.
7. ReactJS: Conditional Rendering, Rendering Lists, and React Forms.
8. ReactJS: React Router for page navigation.
9. ReactJS: Using Hooks and sharing data between components.
10. MongoDB: Installation, Configuration, and CRUD operations.
11. MongoDB: Working with Databases, Collections, and Records.
12. Augmented Programs: Design a to-do list app and a quiz app.

textbooks: Vasan Subramanian, Pro MERN Stack: Full Stack Web App Development with Mongo, Express, React, and Node, 2nd edition, APress, O’Reilly.
Mike Cantelon, Mark Harter, T.J. Holowaychuk, Nathan Rajlich, Node.Js in Action, Manning Publications. (Chapters 1-11)
AzatMardan, React Quickly, Manning Publications, 2nd Edition, 2017.

course_outcomes: Identify the Societal problems.
Solve the problems.
Design of the problem/work plan.
Design of the prototype/model.

syllabus.title: Project Description
syllabus.topics: Carried out during summer vacation for six weeks after Semester 4. Students will go to the society (Villages/ Hospitals/Towns, etc,.) to identify a problem, survey literature for a feasible solution, and are encouraged to solve real life problems leading to innovative model building. This can be done in a group of students or as an individual.

course_outcomes: Execute rational pronunciation of speech sounds including accentuation.
Apply elements of listening comprehension in professional environments.
Develop the abilities of rational argumentation and skills of public speaking.
Demonstrate proficiency in the elements of professional communication including the competitive examination.

syllabus.title: Spoken Expression and Listening Comprehension
syllabus.topics: Speech Mechanism, Articulation of vowels and consonants, Patterns of Accentuation, Types and processes of Listening comprehension.

syllabus.title: Public Speaking
syllabus.topics: Group Discussion(Open and Monitored), Pyramid Discussion, PNI, Seminar Talk and Power Point Presentation.

syllabus.title: Professional Communication
syllabus.topics: Self Affirmation Advanced Composition including Memo and e-mail, R´esum´e Preparation, Corporate ethic of Non-Verbal Communication.

syllabus.title: Life Skills and Vocabulary for Competitive Examinations
syllabus.topics: Select Life Skills(50), Select Logies, Isms, Phobias and Manias (25 each), Sentence Completion and Double Unit Verbal Analogies (50 items), Fundamentals of Syllogisms(Descriptive and Pictorial).

textbooks: M. Cutts, Oxford Guide to Plain English, 7th impression, Oxford, UK: Oxford University Press, 2011.

Department of Phonetics and Spoken English, Exercises in Spoken English, 21st impression, Hyderabad, India: Central Institute of English and Foreign Languages (CIEFL), published by Oxford University Press, 2003.
reference_books: S. R. Covey, The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, 2nd edition, London, UK: Simon & Schuster UK Ltd (Pocket Books), 2004.
J. S. Brubacher, Eclectic Philosophy of Education: A Book of Readings, Englewood Cliffs, NJ, USA: Prentice-Hall, 1951.

course_outcomes: Learns to Implement Flutter Widgets and Layouts
Understand Responsive UI Design and with Navigation in Flutter
Knowledge on Widges and customize widgets for specific UI elements, Themes
Understand to include animation apart from fetching data

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: 1. Install Flutter and Dart SDK.
2. Explore Flutter widgets (Text, Image, Container) and implement layouts (Row, Column, Stack).
3. Design a responsive UI that adapts to different screen sizes using media queries.
4. Set up navigation between screens using Navigator and named routes.
5. Learn about stateful/stateless widgets and implement state management using setState and Provider.
6. Create custom widgets and apply styling using themes.
7. Design a form with various input fields and implement validation.
8. Add animations to UI elements.
9. Fetch data from a REST API and display it in the UI.
10. Write unit tests and use debugging tools.

textbooks: M. L. Napoli, Beginning Flutter: A Hands-on Guide to App Development, Hoboken, NJ, USA: John Wiley & Sons, 2020.
R. Payne, Beginning App Development with Flutter: Create Cross-Platform Mobile Apps, 1st edition, New York, NY, USA: Apress, 2021.
R. Rose, Flutter & Dart Cookbook: Developing Full-Stack Applications for the Cloud, Sebastopol, CA, USA: O’Reilly Media, 2022.

course_outcomes: Understand the corporate etiquette.
Make presentations effectively with appropriate body language.
Be composed with positive attitude.
Understand the core competencies to succeed in professional and personal life.

syllabus.title: Analytical Thinking and Communication Skills
syllabus.topics: Self-Introduction, Shaping Young Minds (Listening Activity), Self–Analysis, Developing Positive Attitude, Perception; Verbal Communication, Non Verbal Communication (Body Language).

syllabus.title: Self-Management Skills and Etiquette
syllabus.topics: Anger Management, Stress Management, Time Management, Six Thinking Hats, Team Building, Leadership Qualities; Social Etiquette, Business Etiquette, Telephone Etiquette, Dining Etiquette.

syllabus.title: Standard Operation Methods and Verbal Ability
syllabus.topics: Note Making, Note Taking, Minutes Preparation, Email Letter Writing; Synonyms, Antonyms, One Word Substitutes, Correction of Sentences, Analogies, Spotting Errors, Sentence Completion, Course of Action, Reading Comprehension.

syllabus.title: Career-Oriented Skills
syllabus.topics: Group Discussion, Mock Group Discussions, Resume Preparation, Interview Skills, Mock Interviews.

reference_books: Mitra, B. K., Personality development and soft skills (Vol. 156). Oxford University Press, 2011.
Dhanavel, S. P, English and Soft Skills. Orient Blackswan Pvt Limited, 2011.
Aggarwal, R. S., A Modern Approach to Verbal & Non Verbal Reasoning. S. Chand, 2018.
Meenakshi, R. & Sharma, S, Technical Communication Principles and Practice, Oxford University Press, 2011.

course_outcomes: Understand the basics of writing technical reports, technical sentence formation, using transitions, and appropriate tenses for technical writing.
Understand the use of drafts, illustrations, grammar, spelling, readability, and writing in plain English for effective technical documentation.
Apply the use of word processor tools such as Table of Contents, citations, footnotes, comments, macros, and document protection.
Understand the nature of Intellectual Property and explain the process of patenting and international cooperation on Intellectual Property.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Technical Writing
syllabus.topics: An introduction to writing technical reports, technical sentences formation, using transitions, using tenses. Planning and Structuring: Planning the report, identifying reader(s), Voice, Formatting, Sections of a technical report, Minutes of meeting writing.

syllabus.title: Drafting and Finalizing Reports
syllabus.topics: The use of drafts, Illustrations and graphics. Final edits: Grammar, spelling, readability and writing in plain English. Proofreading and summaries. Presenting final reports: Printed presentation, Verbal presentation skills, Introduction to proposals.

syllabus.title: Using a Word Processor
syllabus.topics: Adding a Table of Contents, Indexing, Outlines, Comments, Tracking Changes, Footnotes and Endnotes, Inserting citations and Bibliography, Comparing/Combining Documents, Password protection, Using Macros.

syllabus.title: Intellectual Property Rights (IPR)
syllabus.topics: Nature of Intellectual Property: Patents, Designs, Trade and Copyright. Process of Patenting and Development: Technological research, innovation, patenting. International Scenario: International cooperation on Intellectual Property.

textbooks: Kompal Bansal & Parshit Bansal, “Fundamentals of IPR for Beginner’s”, 1st Ed., BS Publications, 2016.
William S. Pfeiffer and Kaye A. Adkins, “Technical Communication: A Practical Approach”, Pearson.
Ramappa,T., “Intellectual Property Rights Under WTO”, 2nd Ed., S Chand, 2015.
reference_books: Adrian Wallwork , English for Writing Research Papers, Springer New York Dordrecht Heidelberg London, 2011.
Day R, How to Write and Publish a Scientific Paper, Cambridge University Press, 2006.

syllabus.title: Internship Description
syllabus.topics: Students must undergo an eight-week industrial/research internship during the summer vacation.

metadata.course_name: Full semester Internship and Project Work
metadata.prerequisites: Not specified in the provided document.

syllabus.title: Project Description
syllabus.topics: The student should undergo an internship and simultaneously work on a project with well-defined objectives. At the end of the semester, the student should submit an internship completion certificate and a project report.
